answer.explanation: Web 2.0 is the era of the internet most people are very familiar with. It has a large focus on community, social media, user experience and how users interact with web pages. Web 2.0 brought the popularity of AJAX and JavaScript for designing dynamic websites. During Web 2.0 there was a large focus on front-end user interfaces and design. One of the major downsides of Web 2.0 is that data is controlled by intermediaries (e.g. Facebook, Google, Amazon etc.) and privacy is lacking.

contents.prompt:
Which of the following internet eras is most commonly associated with the following characteristics?

  • A focus on community.
  • User-generated content and social media.
  • More attention to user experience, front-end user interfaces and website design.
  • Data controlled by intermediaries.

answer.explanation:
A decentralized system is one that is not controlled by a central authority or entity, but instead by the network of particpants that use it. Decentralized systems have many advantages and disadvantages.

Due to the nature of a decentralized system it typically is slower than a centralized system and requires a large amount of computational resources. It has a high network diameter which results in the slow propagation of data. When data conflicts occur resolution is complex and typically relies on advanced protocols and consensus mechanisms.

Decentralized systems have the advantage of security, as there is no single point of failure. They also make censorship and gatekeeping very difficult as control over the network is distributed.

choices: Higher performance, higher throughput and fewer computational resources required.
In the event of conflicting data, resolution is simple and straight forward.
Low network diameter results in information being propagated quickly.
Lack of gatekeepers (i.e., anyone can participate in the network).
contents.prompt: Which of the following are advantages of decentralized systems? Select all that apply.

answer.explanation:
A blockchain is a distributed, decentralized, publicly available ledger of transactions that are verified. Blockchains have the following main characteristics:

  • Immutable
  • Publicly Available
  • Decentralized
  • Distributed
  • Chronological
  • Irrevocable

contents.prompt: Which of the following are characteristics of a blockchain? Select all that apply.

answer.explanation:
Hash functions are special functions that have no known inverse. They are used to generate a hash/digest of an output that is verifiable but not able to be inverted. Hash functions are the foundation of cryptography and have the following properties.

  • Fast to compute
  • Generate uniform output (e.g. same length output)
  • Have no known inverse
  • Determinstic
  • Have very rare hash collisions

contents.prompt: Which of the following are characteristics of hash functions? Select all that apply.

answer.explanation: A private key acts as the password to your wallet/account. With the private key you can access all your funds and send/sign transactions. Your public key is derived from the private key and is what is safe to share with others. The public key is derived by hashing the private key, making it impossible to easily compute the private key associated with a public key. Lastly, we have the address, the address is a more readable version of the public key, it is shorter and easier to work with and is derived from the public key.

choices: An address is derived from the private key which is derived from the public key.
A public key is derived from the private key which is derived from the address.
An address is derived from the public key which is derived from the private key.
A private key is derived from the public key which is derived from the address.
An address is the same thing as a public key, they are both derived from the private key.
contents.prompt: What is the correct relationship between a private key, public key and address?

answer.explanation:
A transaction has both inputs and outputs. The inputs to the transaction are previously received transactions that prove the sender has sufficient balance to send the specified amounts in the output. The outputs of the transaction includes a list of recipients and how much to send to each, a gas/tx fee and change to be returned to the sender.

Note: a digital signature is NOT a part of the transaction outputs. It is generated after the transaction is created by signing the hash of the transaction with the signing key (private key).

contents.prompt: To create a transaction you must include inputs and outputs. What outputs are required for each transaction? Select all that apply.

answer.explanation: A digital signature can be validated using the senders public key, which is also known as the verification key. A miner will use the signature, transaction hash and verification key and be able to validate that this specific transaction was signed by the user possesing the private key associated with the public verification key (the senders public key).

choices: They are verified by miners using the accounts public key.
They are verified by all nodes on the network using the first half of the private key and the public key.
Miners hash the signature and the address of the sender to create the verification key which can validate the signature and transaction data.
contents.prompt: A digital signature is used to prove that the person that created a transaction has access to that accounts private key. How are transaction signatures validated?

answer.explanation: The nonce is an additional value that is determined by miners to provide proof of work. When a block is hashed it's hash must start with a certain number of zeros to be a valid block. To adjust the hash of the block to start with this number of zeros miners guess a nonce, that when added to the block makes the hash valid.

contents.prompt: What is the name of the field that is added to a block by miners to provide a proof of work for that block?

answer.explanation: False! The higher the number of bits the higher the difficulty of that block. The number of bits specifies the number of zeros the hash of the block must start with. The more zeros the more difficult it is to determine a valid nonce.

contents.prompt: A block that specifies a bit value of 20 has a higher difficulty than a block that specifies a bit value of 25.

answer.explanation: On the Bitcoin network miners that successfully mine a block receive a reward that consists of a pre-determined or set block reward, as well transactions fees from included transactions. The block reward is based on the block number and is halved every set number of blocks. The current BTC block reward is 6.25 BTC but started at 50 BTC in 2009.

choices: A block reward proportional to the stake provided by the miner.
contents.prompt: In the Bitcoin proof of work algorithm miners that successfully mine a block receive a reward. What does that reward consist of? Select all that apply.

answer.explanation: False! The difficulty of the network is dependant on the networks total hash rate. The difficulty fluctuates over time and is adjusted every two weeks to ensure that 1 new block is created approximately every 10 minutes.

contents.prompt: On the Bitcoin network the block difficulty always increases over time.

answer.explanation:
Proof of stake and proof of work algorithms both have their advantages and disadvantages, neither is objectively better than the other. The main advantage of proof of stake is the significantly reduced environmental impact. In a proof of stake network, validators require significantly less computational resources and are incentivized to behave ethically due to the collateral/stake they provide, that can be slashed. Proof of stake also has the added benefit of increasing decentralization due to the lack of mining pools.

Where proof of stake may be lacking is in accessibility and financial barriers to entry. If a large stake is required to participate in the validation process many nodes will be unable to participate due to financial limitations.

Note: neither proof of stake or proof of work can said to be objectively more secure than the other. It depends on the decentralization of miners/validators and the participation on the network.

choices: Increased decentralization due to lack of mining pools.
contents.prompt: What are the advantages of a proof of stake algorithm compared to proof of work algorithm?

answer.explanation: Full nodes are simply nodes that contain an entire copy of the blockchain. Mining nodes are always full nodes, however, a full node is not always a mining or validating node. This means full nodes can validate transactions (as they store an entire copy of the blockchain), however, they cannot necessarily create new blocks unless they are also a miner/validator.

choices: Full nodes are synonymous to miner nodes.
Full nodes contain an entire copy of the blockchain.
Full nodes contain an partial copy of the blockchain.
Full nodes can validate transactions and create new blocks.
contents.prompt: Which of the following statements are true as they relate to Full Nodes?

answer.explanation:
A masternode is a special node that acts like a regular node but also facilitates special operations like voting, enforcing laws, etc. Many blockchain networks do not have masternodes.

Hosting a masternode usually requires higher end hardware and that the hosting entity provides a stake/collateral. Masternodes must always be online/available and usually you are compensated for hosting a masternodes.

choices: All blockchain networks have some form of masternodes.
Hosting a masternode typically requires a stake/collateral.
Masternodes usually have lower end hardware than typical nodes.
You are usually compensated for hosting a masternode.
contents.prompt: Which of the following statements are true as they relate to masternodes? Select all that apply.

answer.explanation: Fork chains are rare but can occur. When they do they are typically resolved when the next valid block is mined. The block that this newly added block references as the previous block in it's chain becomes the valid block and the other block (one that resulted in the fork chain) is disregraded.

choices: The blocks that were created at the same time are disregarded and nodes wait for the next new block.
The block that contains the largest number of transactions is considered valid.
Nodes store both blocks and wait for the next block to be mined. The chain this next block is connected to becomes the valid chain.
Nodes wait for a masternode to propagate a resolution and decide the correct chain to continue.
contents.prompt: A fork chain can occur when two valid blocks are mined at the exact same time. How do nodes determine which chain to consider as valid when this occurs?
